body:
I agree, I don't understand the response in #1176, and the tone seems unnecessarily negative. How would someone submit a documentation PR when no clarification was provided on how the current documentation differs from the expected behavior?

My understanding is that `gulp.src()` or `glob-stream` special-cases the negated patterns, but since it uses `glob` under the hood I'd rather use `opts.ignore` than negated patterns, as advised by that package.

Also, there was a bug in `glob` that prevented `opts.ignore` from working in connection with the way `gulp.src()` or `glob-stream` utilizes `glob`: https://github.com/isaacs/node-glob/issues/194. That was fixed relatively recently. I don't know if there's another issue that prevents `opts.ignore` from working through `gulp.src()`, but it's at least worth checking / updating your `glob` dependency to see if that fixes it.
A PR fixing the docs would definitely be welcome :)
@callumacrae What would constitute fixing them? What about the current documentation is inaccurate?
We do not pass through the ignore option - this is on purpose. A PR to correct the docs would be appreciated if you want to help out.

Some questions to help the documentation update be complete:
- Are there any other options besides `ignore` that gulp doesn't pass through?
- Node-glob warned of negation weirdness. Is there anything in particular that we should caution users against?
- Node-glob warned about dropping negation support? If this happens, will gulpfiles break? Is there anything we should include to assuage concerns or help users future-proof their code?

@breyed 
- AFAIK we pass through everything, but ignore just does nothing because we do our own negation
- globs are executed in order, but this is already in the docs about negation in src
- glob already dropped negation, which doesn't effect us because we never relied on it and never passed through the ignore option

We have always done our own negation for consistency and performance reasons.

Just to explain more:

``` js
gulp.src(['client/*.js', '!client/b*.js', 'client/bad.js'])
```

ends up internally (in .src) as

``` js
getFiles('client/*.js')
  .pipe(ignoreFiles('client/b*.js'))
  .pipe(getFiles('client/bad.js'))
```

So given the following directory structure

```
client/
  a.js
  bob.js
  bad.js
```

You will get `a.js` and `bad.js` out of the stream.

``` js
gulp.src(['app/**/*', '!app/node_modules/**/*'])
```

Will still traverse the node modules folder, but then negate at the vinyl-fs level which is a huge CPU and memory hog. Somebody sent a PR to fix this by using the node-glob ignore option so it won't crawl anything it shouldn't, but that PR never got merged due to some issues in node-glob: https://github.com/gulpjs/glob-stream/pull/40

body:
@contra 

> We do not pass through the ignore option - this is on purpose.
> AFAIK we pass through everything, but ignore just does nothing because we do our own negation

I think you're saying that the gulp stuff doesn't _set_ an `ignore` option (it implements negation by other means), but does pass it through if the user passed it. Is there some specific reason at this time that passing `ignore` to `gulp.src()` wouldn't be viable? As of a few months ago there was a bug in `glob` that would prevent `ignore` from working in conjunction with the way the gulp stuff utilizes `glob`, but that was supposed to be fixed as of v5.0.13.

> We have always done our own negation for consistency and performance reasons.
> Will still traverse the node modules folder, but then negate at the vinyl-fs level which is a huge CPU and memory hog.

These comments are kind of hard to reconcile. The custom negation stuff is better or worse for performance? If `glob`'s `ignore` works is there a performance advantage to the custom gulp negation? Not sure what the consistency issues are.

@jmm 
- What's your use case for not wanting to put the negations in the array? Why are you so keen on using the ignore option?
- As far as "not viable" I don't think the ignore option to the underlying glob module will play well with our stuff, but feel free to try that yourself
- The performance isn't black and white, it has nuances - doing our own negation is fast in most cases, and slow in that one specific case. 

I guess I'm just confused about this whole series of github threads: Can you clearly explain what the desired outcome of this looks like to you?

@contra
- > What's your use case for not wanting to put the negations in the array? Why are you so keen on using the ignore option?
  
  Originally, because the gulp documentation implies that it passes the patterns through to node-glob:
  
  > `glob` refers to [node-glob syntax](https://github.com/isaacs/node-glob)
  
  Where the node-glob documentation linked to tells you not to use negated patterns and to use `ignore` instead:
  
  > The intent for negation would be for a pattern starting with `!` to match everything that _doesn't_ match the supplied pattern. However, the implementation is weird, and for the time being, this should be avoided. The behavior is deprecated in version 5, and will be removed entirely in version 6.
  > 
  > Note: In version 5 of this module, negation and comments are disabled by default....They are going away entirely in version 6.
  > 
  > It is better to use the `ignore` option
  
  I don't see anything in the gulp docs that explains that it special-cases negated patterns. In fact negated patterns or ignoring paths are barely even _mentioned_. I see one example of a negated pattern, with no commentary, in the main [README](https://github.com/gulpjs/gulp/blob/master/README.md). I don't see _anything_ about it in the [`gulp.src()` docs](https://github.com/gulpjs/gulp/blob/master/docs/API.md#gulpsrcglobs-options). Realistically, most people aren't going to think there's any reason to look at the glob-stream docs, which in any case still don't explain that negated patterns are special-cased and still say that options are passed through to node-glob.
  
  I only discovered that gulp special-cases negated patterns when I noticed that the `ignore` option didn't work. I fully expected it to since the gulp docs say that the options are:
  
  > [passed] to node-glob through glob-stream.
  
  That's when I discovered https://github.com/isaacs/node-glob/issues/194 and chalked it up to that. 
  
  Now that I know all of this I'd still prefer to be consistent with the underlying implementation (node-glob) and use `ignore` unless there's an important reason to rely on gulp's special-casing of the negated patterns.
- > As far as "not viable" I don't think the ignore option to the underlying glob module will play well with our stuff, but feel free to try that yourself
  
  Yeah I'll plan to give it a shot.

> I guess I'm just confused about this whole series of github threads: Can you clearly explain what the desired outcome of this looks like to you?

What series is that, this and #1176? Desired outcome:
- Find out if `ignore` does or doesn't work and why.
- Find out if there is or isn't some important reason to rely on gulp's special-casing of negated patterns instead.
- Make any necessary corrections to the documenation.
- Don't have the documentation say you can't use `ignore` unless you really can't and shouldn't.
- Help you understand how the documentation and comments regarding this are confusing for your users.

@jmm

People should not be using the ignore option, this is an API decision we made and why the option is not documented (or recommended, or talked about) anywhere - however, we do not prevent people from passing the ignore option to node-glob under the hood if they are familiar with the internals and have a special case.

Nowhere in our documentation do we tell people to use the ignore option, and we have a section about globs and glob negation that shows how we expect users to do it. If a user wants to know how to do glob negation they can read our documentation that explains how to do glob negation.

Look, I understand our docs are a mess. I don't need you to explain that to me, I'm not an idiot. I am sincerely sorry if our documentation confused you. Really. But let's focus on fixing it so we don't have to keep sending paragraphs back and forth.

Can you send a PR that solves this? I can't seem to get on your wavelength and understand your desired solution, so I think it would be easier for both of us if you go ahead and make your changes.

@jmm 

> Nowhere in our documentation do we tell people to use the ignore option

The old documentation effectively did tell people to use `ignore`. When the docs just say "this module passes options through to module _x_", you're telling users to freely use all the options of module _x_.

A PR to fix the documentation already exists. What @contra is asking about is whether we should go further. He's asking whether the API decision to not use `ignore` is the right decision. A PR isn't a bad way to answer the question: see if it's practical to implement an API that matches node-glob's.

The one caveat I'd put out there is that if anyone would be against an `ignore`-based API even if it has a solid implementation behind it, please speak now before @contra invests time into the PR.
